summary: Indexing into an Array with a String shouldn't be an error

comments.content:
The JSC_INVALID_GETELEM_INDEX_ERROR is a huge fallacy.  It would be fine if it was a warning, but 
as an error it keeps perfectly fine JavaScript from compiling.

Raphael.js doesn't compile because it uses strings to improve minification, such as [1,2][push](3) 
where the push variable was defined earlier.

Also, simple code like this won't compile:
[1,2][i ? 'push' : 'unshift'](i);

As you can see, these are very valid uses of JavaScript and should *not* throw errors.
I was not able to reproduce this. Can you give more detailed repro steps?
oh, now i see it. ya, that's just a bug.

Also, i should mention that aliasing "push" does not improve minification on a decent 
web server. A decent web server will gzip the JavaScript. And this "minification" will 
actually make the gzipped code larger.

That's good to note, but I didn't write Raphael, I'd just like to compile it.  :-)

Thanks a lot for the quick response!
this should be fixed as of r34. (i'll mark it fixed when we cut a real release).
